metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Python Numbers
Python Numbers
There are three numeric types in Python:
content.html: There are three numeric types in Python:

content.text: Variables of numeric types are created when you assign a value to them:
content.html: Variables of numeric types are created when you assign a value to them:

content.code_html:
x = 1    # int
y = 2.8  # float
z = 1j   # complex

content.text: To verify the type of any object in Python, use the type() function:
content.html: To verify the type of any object in Python, use the type() function:

content.code_html:
print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

content.text: Int
Int, or integer, is a whole number, positive or negative, without decimals, of unlimited length.
content.html: Int, or integer, is a whole number, positive or negative, without decimals, of unlimited length.

content.code_html:
x = 1
y = 35656222554887711
z = -3255522

print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

content.text: Float
Float, or "floating point number" is a number, positive or negative, containing one or more decimals.
content.html: Float, or "floating point number" is a number, positive or negative, containing one or more decimals.

content.code_html:
x = 1.10
y = 1.0
z = -35.59

print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

content.text: Float can also be scientific numbers with an "e" to indicate the power of 10.
content.html: Float can also be scientific numbers with an "e" to indicate the power of 10.

content.code_html:
x = 35e3
y = 12E4
z = -87.7e100

print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

content.text: Complex
Complex numbers are written with a "j" as the imaginary part:
content.html: Complex numbers are written with a "j" as the imaginary part:

content.code_html:
x = 3+5j
y = 5j
z = -5j

print(type(x))
print(type(y))
print(type(z))

content.text: Type Conversion
You can convert from one type to another with the int() , float() , and complex() methods:
content.html: You can convert from one type to another with the int(), float(), and complex() methods:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
x = 1    # inty = 2.8  # floatz = 1j   # complex#convert from int to float:
  a = float(x)#convert from float to int:
  b = int(y)#convert from int to complex:c = complex(x)print(a)print(b)
  print(c)print(type(a))print(type(b))
  print(type(c))

content.code:
x = 1    # inty = 2.8  # floatz = 1j   # complex#convert from int to float:
a = float(x)#convert from float to int:
b = int(y)#convert from int to complex:c = complex(x)print(a)print(b)
print(c)print(type(a))print(type(b))
print(type(c))

syntax_highlighting.text:
x = 1    # inty = 2.8  # floatz = 1j   # complex#convert from int to float:
  a = float(x)#convert from float to int:
  b = int(y)#convert from int to complex:c = complex(x)print(a)print(b)
 print(c)print(type(a))print(type(b))
 print(type(c))

content.code_html:
x = 1    # int
y = 2.8  # float
z = 1j   # complex

#convert from int to float:
 a = float(x)

#convert from float to int:
 b = int(y)

#convert from int to complex:
c = complex(x)

print(a)
print(b)
print(c)

print(type(a))
print(type(b))
print(type(c))

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
x = 1    # inty = 2.8  # floatz = 1j   # complex#convert from int to float:
  a = float(x)#convert from float to int:
  b = int(y)#convert from int to complex:c = complex(x)print(a)print(b)
  print(c)print(type(a))print(type(b))
  print(type(c))

content.text: Note: You cannot convert complex numbers into another number type.
content.html: Note: You cannot convert complex numbers into another number type.

content.text: Random Number
Python does not have a random() function to make a random number, but Python has a built-in module called random that can be used to make random numbers:
content.html: Python does not have a random() function to make a random number, but Python has a built-in module called random that can be used to make random numbers:

content.code_html:
import random

print(random.randrange(1, 10))

content.text: In our Random Module Reference you will learn more about the Random module.
content.html: In our Random Module Reference you will learn more about the Random module.
